channel.title: First C Program

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:29, topic:308188”][quote author=Cheese_Police link=topic=404320.msg3030449#msg3030449 date=1258331777]

[quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=404320.msg3029719#msg3029719 date=1258284590]

Wouldn’t you rather write in C++, or is there a hidden benefit to coding in C still?

Wouldn’t you rather write in Java, or is there a hidden benefit to coding in C++ still?

If you don’t care about responsiveness, memory efficiency, quality or performance, you can still use better languages than Java, such as C# or Python. Only benefit Java really provides over C++ is compiler speed, reflection, anotations, and a big sucky std lib. Java is missing the features I mentioned above, plus in its core unsigned types, templates, free standing functions, low level access, raw pointers, SBRM, operator overloading, friendness, etc.
[/quote]JAVA HAS ITS OWN TEMPLATES, LEAVE JAVA ALONE YOU ARE UPSETTING IT, ITS NOT JAVAS FAULT THAT IT DOESNT HAVE UNSIGNED TYPES AND JAVA BELIEVES THAT MOST PEOPLE CAN FIND WAYS ROUND THAT SO PLZ PLZ PLZ LEAVE IT ALONE! On the other hand java is a high level memory munching bastard of a language.

The Java language specification 3.0 refers to Generics as such, and does not mention Templates. C++ templates are resolved on compile time and hence a template instance of a template class is just as fast as it would be if they had been implemented separatedly. On the other side, Java generics are just syntactic sugar for casts and are hence slower, must be applicable for all cases, do not support primitive types, do not support non-types, do not support specialization, etc.

Java generics are not templates. The differences are clear.
[/quote]Yes but they are named templates. Forgive me for trying to help Java’s cause here.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

-pedantic

void game(int num) {
	int guessval = -1;
	while(guessval - num) {
		guessval = userguess();
		if (guessval > num) {
			printf("Too high!\n");
		} else if (guessval < num) {
			printf("Too low!\n");
		} else {
			printf("Correct!\n");
		}
	}
}

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Here is an improved version that I made:

#define INPUT_LEN 256

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <time.h>

void game(int);
int userguess();

int main() {
	srand(time(NULL));
	game(rand() % 50);
	getchar();
	return 0;
}

void game(int num) {
	while(1) {
		int guessval = userguess();
		if (guessval > num) {
			printf("Too high!\n");
		} else if (guessval < num) {
			printf("Too low!\n");
		} else {
			printf("Correct!\n");
			break;
		}
	}
}

int userguess() {
	printf("Enter a number: ");
	char input[INPUT_LEN];
	fgets(input, INPUT_LEN, stdin);
	return atoi(input);
}

meh?

edit: cain and abrhm are nubs.

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Speljohan:

Wat, since when isn’t java user-friendly?

I was kinda referring to C++'s “friend” classes and functions, not to user-friendliness

Java is indeed relatively user-friendly, assuming you stay within certain bounds (such as away from the JNI)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 30, 2009, 11:53:13 am[/size][hr][quote=“oksuper_, post:19, topic:308188”]l2 jna[/quote]

The JNA library is certainly better than raw JNI. Java would gain some points if it included it in its std library. And some extra points if it provided a seamless custom syntax around it, just like C#'s. And unsigned types, now that we’re on it. Having to use 8 bytes to represent a 4 bytes integer properly is as dumb as it gets.

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Yep, exactly what qauters says

Although as mentioned above C# is just as safe as Java, it still lets you take the decision to leave that safety aside for a while to do things you otherwise couldn’t. Calling a WINAPI, for example, is maybe a bit more verbose than in C, for example, yet as you can see in Qauters example nobody would find it particularly troublesome, and at the same time nobody would use an unsafe operation by mistake.

In Java however, you’d have to use the JNI which adds a whole new layer of complexity, and in fact requires using a different language ( C / C++…) and an API that is not particularly user friendly. That does not only require much more code, but it also requires you to know to some extent a different language and an obscure particular API for it, plus using two languages hinders maintenability significantly. It also increases the chances of bugs, because now you’ve a significant portion of native code which can easily segfault.

Personally, I wouldn’t touch the JNI with a ten-foot pole if I could avoid it, and I happen to know both Java and C++. The average Java-only programmer would hardly even consider it an option. For a language that strives for simplicity, and that sacrifices a lot of things to achieve it, a system such as the JNI is particularly out of place.

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Mopman:

How is P/Invoke more “built in” than JNI, out of curiosity?

You can directly access native dll’s from .NET, without having to write a wrapper dll using JNI.
Which is probably what he means

Like:

[DllImport("User32.dll")]
static extern Boolean MessageBeep(UInt32 beepType);

Read full topic

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:9, topic:308188”]did you not see that super_ was trolling?

and how is c# better than a language like java? how i see it, java and c# are both dynamically interpreted, yet java carries the advantage that it is compiled into bytecode, rather than native code (ie CLI), and is therefore portable to any system that contains its respective jit compiler (jvm) without the requisite of using yet another project (mono) to accomplish it

oh ya, and forget the fact that .nets garbage collector is bloated as fuck, and that java applications are ran in a “memory-protected” environment, and such things like memory leakage, undefined behavior, and segmentation faults are non existent to those programmers who have at least a minimal clue as to what they are doing[/quote]

As people have said already, Java and C# work in the same way, both compile to bytecode. (The CLI is a bytecode). There is also no “another” requirement, as Mono by itself can execute .NET assemblies. I’m afraid your claims about memory management and protection and garbage collection are also wrong, as, again, C# and Java’s scheme is the same, with the single exception of C# being more powerful and supporting native interaction as a built-in extra rather than as a different API (The JNI). The performance of each system is relative and discussing it is mostly irrelevant as if we wanted particular performance we would probably use neither. The benchmarks I have seen (Mono ones) seem to suggest that Java has a higher CPU throughput, whereas C# Mono provides better memory efficiency.

On a different note, I do agree that currently Java probably has a higher deployment rate than .NET. However, C# is an ECMA standard and the Mono implementation is Open Source. Though it would obviously be nice that Microsoft explicitally supported it, Linux and other projects do not belong to any company and they fare well enough. Novell happens to be Mono’s sponsor anyway, and several others provide commercial support too (Just like there are companies that provide commercial Linux support).

Nonetheless, originally I was simply referring to C# being significantly more powerful as language. Especifically, it provides the same features (including reflection, a large library, attributes (anotations), compiler speed), plus a lot of important ones which Java (and sometimes even C++) doesn’t support: Unsigned types, properties, operator overloading, stack-based structures, delegates, built-in limited native calls and pointers support, primitive generics (which also generate actual unique code to each instance) automatic type-inferring var declaration support, closures (and lambdas), partial classes, partial methods, class extensions, preprocessing, etc etc.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

you mean CIL, right? if so, how is CIL native code? (ps CLI is common language infrastructure)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 29, 2009, 12:14:46 am[/size][hr]also, since when did jvm == jit compileR? and you do know .net runs in a similar environment?

item.title: First C Program
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

C# is compiled to a ‘bytecode’ intermediate form of sorts that can run on multiple machines as long as they have a ‘VM’ of sorts (mono for one). It is just only supported by the main vendor (microsoft) on windows, unlike the main vendor of java (sun) supporting multiple operating systems and architectures.

Read full topic
